text: you have to run 26.2 miles to finish a
marathon what's happening to your body
when you're running this far here are
four things that scientists have found
you run a fever during a marathon your
internal core temperature rises up to
102 degrees Fahrenheit your body is
constantly sweating to try and stay cool
it's hard to replenish 100% of what
you've lost a sweat you become more
dehydrated farther you run which makes
it harder for your body to cool itself
the end result is you become feverishly
hot you risk hypothermia after you're
done running your core is still hot so
you continue to try and shed heat if
it's cold outside you risk losing too
much heat too fast
this can cause hypothermia that's why
runners wear thermal blankets after were
raised your kidneys aren't happy in the
small study researchers examined kidney
function 82% of runners had Stage one
acute kidney injury right after a
marathon that means their kidneys had
stopped filtering toxins the body
usually recovers in about two weeks
long-term damage on the kidneys is
unclear you are literally starving you
store around 2,000 calories of glucose
on average you'll burn a hundred of
those calories each mile after 20 miles
your body is literally starving
in response it wants to shut down and
reserve energy if you keep running your
muscles have a harder time functioning
runners call this hitting the wall the
upside carp loading a few days before
maximizes glucose reserves
so far this year over 100 31,000 people
have finished a marathon if you're
planning for one just remember to treat
your body right
